instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-2838: What is 820-2838? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U7201: What is U7201? U7201 is responsible for the 3.3v and 5v power rails on many devices..
definitions.P3V3S3_EN: What is P3V3S3_EN? P3V3S3_EN is a signal that turns on the PP3V3_S3 power rail when it is high. Signals with _EN on the end enable whatever came before the _EN if the signal is high. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2838</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - No <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S3</SIGNAL>.
threads.message:
Customer claims "it just stopped working"; I know Duke always says 'it didn't just stop working!!" but this board is really clean with nice shiny TP all over the place.

Green / Orange light as expected.

<CHIP>U7201</CHIP>::2 == 0v. So no <SIGNAL>PP5V_S3_REG</SIGNAL>.

I get no <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S3</SIGNAL>, looking around <TRANSISTOR>Q7910</TRANSISTOR> and Pins 1,2, 5,& 6 are 0v and pins 3 & 4 are 3.3v.
I think <TRANSISTOR>Q7903</TRANSISTOR> is not getting <SIGNAL>P3V3S3_EN</SIGNAL>, but this won't trigger without <SIGNAL>PP5V_S3_REG</SIGNAL> right?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2838</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - No <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S3</SIGNAL>.
threads.message: Did you short the power pads on the board? These do not auto power on!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2838</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - No <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S3</SIGNAL>.
threads.message: Yes, shorted the pads to try turn it on.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2838</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - No <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S3</SIGNAL>.
